3CE TKIINS
VOL. XXV. No. 25
LACROSSE TEAM DOWNS
PENN IN FIRST LEAGUE
GAME OF SEASON.
Muddy Field Mars Play and Makes
Good Stickwork Almost Impossible — Greee Material Is
Showing Up in Fine
Form—Score 9 to 2.

In the first league game of the
year Hopkins defeated Pennsylvania, 9 to 2, at •Homewood on
Saturday. Due to the bad weather, only a small crowd was on
hand, but those who braved the
rain were treated to a fine game
of lacrosse. Pennsylvania put out
a much stronger team than usual.
Their stickwork was good; they
were fast and aggressive, and had
lots of fight. The lead of seven
goals does not, however, by any
Means show the comparative
strength of the two teams. The
wet, muddy field put both teams •
on an equality, making the running hard, dodging almost impossible and the bouncing of the ball
erratic. The stickwork was below
standard at times also, due to the
wet ball slipping out of the stick.
Had the field been a dry one the
score would without doubt have
been greater. Throughout the
game Hopkins showed a strong attack, good teamwork and the ability to shoot hard and accurately
after the ball had been worked
The point that
dOWn the field.
was especially noticeable was how
well the midfield worked in with
the close attack, and with several
weeks more practice it looks as if
the coaches will have developed
out of green material an attack
that will equal Hopkins' best.
The defense also played a strong
game, although its part was not
as heavy Saturday as that of the
attack. Zoller broke up play after
play. While at goal Benedict
stopped any number Of hard shots.
:Navy beat Penn 10 to 0 on a dry
field; we beat them 9 to 2 on a
wet field. All we can say is
"Bring on Navy!"
Parsons shot the first goal of
the day with a pretty shot after
clever passing by Zoller and Huey.
Griffiss made the next two goals,
both of them being hard corner
shots from the side of the field.
He was the only man who seemed
to be able to keep his feet when
running hard, and his dodging
was one of the features of the
game. Prengle scored for Penn at
this time on a pass from Kiviat
over goal. Bauernschinidt, who
substituted for McDaniel, made
the last score of the half by picking up the ball off the ground and
making a pretty corner shot.
Penn came back strong in the
second half, and except for one
goal by Boyd held Hopkins score(Continued on page 4 col. 3)

BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 26, 1921
MUSICAL CLUBS SCORE HIT
IN CHURCH CONCERT.
Franklin Square Baptists Applaud Selections—All Performers in Fine
Form—University Ode Well
Received.

The Johns Hopkins combined
si cal clubs presented an unusually -snappy" and successful concert at the Franklin Square Baptist Church on Thursday evening,
April 21. The University Ode sung
by the Glee Club deserves silecial
mention, judging by the lasting
applause of an appreciative audience. As usual, the Glee Club and
the Mandolin Club were led by
"Doug" Coulter and "Mike" Bowers, respectively.
The concert began with a selection played by the orchestra. The
members of the Mandolin Club
distinguished themselves in rendering the "dreamily" waltz, "Hiawatha's Melody of Love." Next on
the program was "On the Road to
Mandalay." Eric Calkins sang the
solo part with great brilliancy. A
second solo took place later in the
evening when Waldo Hambleton
played "The Rosary" on his steel
guitar. According to the colored
sexton of the church, the -jazz" orchestra was "de hole sho" when it
jazzed up, -I Never. Knew." The
Barcarole played by the Mandolin
Club brought a successful evening
to a close. Although the hall was
small, it was filled to its capacity
by a large and appreciative audience.
MIKE BOWERS IS AT IT
AGAIN.
Starts a Student Band, Which Shows
Great Promise—Will Perform at
All Games.

Through the untiring efforts of
"Mike" Bowers, Hopkins has taken
another step in the right direction
with the successful organization
of a student band. After several
fruitless attempts, "Mike," assisted bv C. R. Tatun and backed by
Mr. -Kistler and Mr. Van Orman,
has brought together enough musicians to form a strong organization.
A great deal of interest is being
shown throughout the studentbody toward the movement. There
are at present some twenty-four
members, but it is expected that
many more will join the ranks before very long. Practice is held
two afternoons a week at the Barn,
and from the tone of the last rehearsal, it seemed as though this
band will compare_ favorably with
that of Lafayette, which is said to
be the best college band in the
country.
The band is to furnish music at
all the Saturday afternoon con-

PRICE 10 CENTS

ANNUAL TRIANGULAR DEBATE TAKES PLACE NEXT
SATURDAY.

SOUTHERN INTERCOLLEGIATE NEWSPAPER ASSOCIATION FORMED.

Washington and Lee Meets North Carolina at Homewood—Immigration
Is Subject—Dance Will Follow Debate — Hopkins
Teams Speak Away.

Nearly Forty Delegates From Seven
Southern States Present at Richmond Conference — Cotton
and Miller Rpresent the
News-Letter.

On this Saturday, April 30, the
annual triangular debate between
North Carolina, Washington and
Lee and Johns Hopkins will be
held. As has been the custom in
the past, all three meetings will be
held the same night, with the two
teams of each institution debating
away from home. Accordingly,
the negative team of North Carolina will try conclusions with the
affirmative team from 'Washington
and Lee in the C. E. Hall at Homewood, while the Hopkins affirmative debaters Dorsey Watkins and
Parker Williams are at Chapel
Hill, N. C., meeting the Washington and Lee men, and the negative
team, Adolphus Emmart and Albert Dimond, visit Lexington with
the Tar Heel speakers.
The subject of the debate is "Resolved, that the United States
should adopt a policy of further
material restriction of immigration."
Following the debate, "Mike"
Bowers and his cohorts will fuynish the necessary cacaphony for
an informal dance. Admission to
the hall is prohibited after 8.30;
hence, those who wish to dance
must also be present for the debate. Tickets may be obtained
from Bartus Trew, O. D. Collins
and R. M. Wood.

Charles F. Leet, editor-in-chief
of the Richmond Collegian, the
the weekly publication of the University of Richmond, was last Saturday elected president of the
Southern Intercollegiate Newspaper Association. This association
of the college newspapers of institutions below the Mason and
Dixon line formally began its first
year with the adoption of a constitution and by-laws at the first
annual convention, held at the
University of Richmond last Friday and Saturday.
Nearly twoscore delegates, representing the publications of 20
colleges in seven Southern States,
registered at convention headquarters Friday morning, most of them
ha -ing arrived in Richmond that
morning or the night before. The
conference was opened with an address • of welcome by Dr. F. W.
Boatwright, president of the university, after which Mr. Leek was
elected temporary chairman of the
meeting. After the usual preliminary business and an address iy
Mr. John Stewart Bryan, secretary American Newspaper Publishers' Association, the conference adjourned for luncheon, and
in the afternoon took a tour of inspection through the plant of the
Richmond Erening Dispatch. At
the banquet held that night the attention of the delegates was held
by the remarkable addresses of
Dr. John W. Camlitie, director of
the School of Journalism, Columbia UniverSity, and Dr. Douglas
Freeman, editor of the Richmond
Yeirs-Leader.
The conference was reopened
the next morning by a talk by
Frank M. Dobson, athletic director of the university, who took
as his subject "College Athletes
and the College Paper." Reports
of the several committees were
next presented, the committee on
organization, of which H. D. Cotton, who, with N. E. Miller, Jr.,
represented Johns Hopkins at hte
convention, was chairman, placing before the delegates a proposed constitution and by-laws
which, after a few changes, were
accepted.
The chief object of the association is to draw together, for the
purpose of closer co-operation, the
college newspapers of the South.
Practically all of these papers are

0. D. K. ELECTS.

At a meeting of Omicron Delta
Kappa, held last Friday, several
new men were elected to membership. Their names will be made
public on May 12, when a public
initiation will be held at the Assembly.
tests at "Homewood," and will
also be on hand at other student
gatherings. Mr. Kistler made an
announcement to the effect that
all members of the band would
have the same rating as members
of the athletic teams in that they
would be presented with complimentary tickets to the games. This
announcement should do much to
increase both the spirit and the
number of the musicians.
The organizer should certainly
be congratulated for his great success. Just such an organization
has long been needed on the Hopkins Campus to stir up interest.
As Mr. Van Orman has said, "A
band does as much to stir up school
spirit as a football team."

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, APRIL 26, 1921

BLUE JAY
AND
FACULTY COMMITTEE ON , BLACK
COMES OUT THIS MONTH
MILITARY ACTIVITIES
WITH A BANG.
APPOINTED.
Emphasizes Growth of Importance of
R. 0. T. C. at Hopkins—Unit Getting in Trim for "Distinguished" Inspection.

"Wine, Woman and Song" Leaves Out
Likker and Jazz, But the Women
Are Right There—Will Issue
a Song Book Shortly.

President Goodnow has recently
appointed a Military Committee of
the faculty to co-ordinate the activities of the University and those
Ithe Department of Military
Science and Tactics. The coni'mittee has as chairman, Prof. J.
Herbert Gregory, as vice-chairman,
Dr. William B. Kouwenhoven, and
as secretary, Dr. Ronald T. Abercrombie. The members of the committee are at present making themselves familiar with the technical
details of the work of the military
department. The committee is designed to form a connecting link
between the military department
and the board of collegiate studies.
It has been constituted, moreover,
with the idea of being a University
check on the activities of the military department, and it is believed
that it will form, in the future, a
most useful and constructive body
in fitting the military activities in
with University traditions and
policy. The idea of such a committee was originated some months
ago bv Major Garey, and its establishment marks the recognition on
the part of the faculty of the important place the military department has won for itself among similar institutions throughout the
country.
The percentage of Johns Hopkins men attending R. 0. T. C.
slimmer camp this year is greater,
it is believed, than that of any
other institution in the country.
Major Garey, senior instructor at
the Plattsburg Camp, intends to
grade both individuals and institutions at the camp on their efficiency and ability. A special class
has been formed here for study
preparatory to the subsequent
work at camp, with the purpose of
putting . this institution number
one at Plattsburg.
The finishing touches for this
year's inspection for rating as a
"distinguished" unit are being put
upon the drill of the battalion.
The inspectors this year will be
from the Third Corps Area, instead of from the General Staff at
Washington, as formerly. Our
commandant appeals to the members of the R. 0. T. C. to put their
every effort into the military work
until the end of the year, in order
that we primarily may serve well
the interests of national defense,
and secondarily may come out
with an exceedingly high average
in comparison with other Units.
Major Garey also expressed himself as wishing the sympathy and
moral backing of the entire University in the accomplishment of
these objects.

The wine, women and song number of the Black and Blue Jay
"casts a thunderbolt into the generally dignified campus at Homewood," according to the Baltimore
8un. It compliments the staff on
producing a "snappy" number and
quotes a few articles which were
considered to produce the "pep."
Nor is this all. The general concensus of opinion seems to accept
this issue as the best of the year.
The Grad's number, however, in
which the Jay makes its final flutter of the term, promises to exceed
,its predecessor in "snappiness" if
it receives the support of the university.
The magazine is essentially a
representative of the student-body
and as such deserves unlimited
aid by way of contributions.
A song book is being planned by
the Jay and will probably make
its debut sometime next year. This
does not mark a divergence from
the ordinary line of university publications, for they are used by
nearly all the leading colleges.
This book will include all of the
old traditional songs of Hopkins,
as well as a great number of new
ones. The faculty and the 0. D. K.
are backing this undertaking
strongly, and it is conceded by all
that a song book represents a progressive step at Homewood.
NOTED

ORNITHOLOGIST
LECTURES.

"Migration of Birds" Subject of Lec••
ture.

The Scientific Club was addressed las Friday, April 22, by
Dr. H. C. Oberholser, of the Smithsonian Institution, Washington,
D. C. Quite a large audience was
present to hear the ornithologist
lecture on "The Migration of
Birds."
There are, he said, two theories
of the origin of migration.
First, that the birds migrated
from the tropics, due to overcrowding, and second, that they, originally occupying the galcial zone,
were driven away by the sheets of
ice.
All birds do not migrate. The
migrants, however, are followed
by means of leg-bands and much
interesting data has been compiled.
The birds travel mostly at night,
at rates varying from 20 to 150
miles an hour, and covering distances as great as 11,000 miles.
The normal migration, however, is
about 2000 miles.
The birds frequently return to
their first breeding grounds, travelling entirely by instinct.

NEW OFFICER ASSIGNED TO
HOPKINS.

El

Major Dixon to Make a Specialty of the
Rifle Work of the University.

...The...

One of the best shots in the
world, a former national champion
in rapid fire and member of an
army winning rifle team, has been
detailed to Johns Hopkins as one
of the staff of the military department. Major Blaine A. Dixon, U.
S. Infantry, retired, -was, a classmate of Major Garey'R at West
Point. His coming to the University is prophetic of Hopkins soon
having one of the best rifle, teams
in the country. Major Dixon is to
coach not only members of She
0. T.. C., but any students of the
Unversity who are interested in
shooting.
Already under our new officer's
supervision, an indoor range is be-,
ing constructed by the students beneath the North Grandstand at
Homewood Field. The approval of
President Goodnow and Police
Commissioner Gaither for this
work was obtained last Thursday,
and in the afternoon many heavy
bags of cinders were transported
by willing, but soon, very hot and
tired would-be officers.

MUSICAL CLUBS ACTIVE
THIS SPRING.
Three Successful Concerts Given.
Homewood Concert and Dance
on May 7.

The Johns Hopkins Musical
Club has entered with great success upon its spring schedule. On
April 15 the club presented a concert to the pupils of the Eastern
High School. On April 21, the
members of Franklin Square Baptist Church were highly entertained by the club. On April 23,
the annual concert at State Normal School was given. On April
29, the club will again visit Towson to present a concert for Eddie
Stuart, a Hopkins graduate.
On Saturday, May 7, the Musical Club will give its Homewood
concert. This will be the crowning event of the year for the organization. The program will consist of only the choicest numbers
available, and will be characterized by the snap and pep for which
the club is famous. After the concert there will be an informal
(lance. T. F. Hubbard, manager
of the club, has arranged that the
tickets may be sold for fifty cents
so that all will have an opportunity of enjoying the treat. The
tickets will be necessarily limited
in number, so men wishing to attend should purchase tickets from
any member of the club as soon as
possible in order to be accommodated.

The club intends to inaugurate
a series of popular science meetings for the general public, in addition to the regular meetings. All 0

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LE FTER, APRIL 26, 1921
DRAMATIC CLUB WILL HAVE
AN ADVISORY COUNCIL
OF ALUMNI.
Will Help Maintain Standards of Club.
Aid in Selection of Production and
Cast—Banquet and Election
Planned.

After much deliberation and a
conference in the studio last Tuesday the Dramatic Club has decided
to create an Advisory Council to
assist in forming the policy of the
club and in keeping it up to the
standards it has held during the
three years of its existence. The
definite plans as to the powers of
this Advisory Council will be formulated after various suggestions
are brought up at a meeting today
in the Barn. In all probability it
will consist of from three to five
members, alumni of the University
and former members of the club,
who will be chosen annually. It
will have a voice in choosing the
annual major production and will
spend a great part of its time in
reviewing plays suitable for a Hopkins cast. The choice of a coach
will be wholly in its hands. It is
not intended that this council shall
in any way be mandatory or arbitrary, but that it shall submit
plans and give advice which will
assist in maintaining a high standard of production. Through it
the older members will keep in active touch with the activities of
the club.
Further plans are being made
for the production of several oneact playlets in the studio. It is
hoped that a 'Play-night" can be
arranged for the early part of May.
- An informal banquet, at which officers for next year will be chosen,
will be held at the Johns Hopkins Club.
JUNIOR CLASS DOES A LOT
AT ONE MEETING.
Banquet Committee Appointed — Banquet at Chateau Hotel—Editor and
Manager of Hullabaloo Elected.

A meeting of the Junior Class
was held last Thursday, at 2.20 in
the C. E. Hall.
President Hall announced that
the banquet committee had made
arrangements for the banquet to
be held in the roof-,garden of The
Chateau, the price to be about
$4.00 a plate. As in former years,
satisfactory entertainment will be
provided. The committee is composed of Naviasky (chairman),
Hensel, Johnston and Frank.
Following the election' to the
class of several new members, announcement was made by Huey
that class pictures were on hand
and copies might be purchased.
The rest of the meeting was devoted to the election of Editor and
Business Manager of the Hullabaloo for next year. Dorsey Watkins, secretary of last year, was
elected to fill the first office, while
Huey was selected for the post of
Business Manager.
Another meeting will be held in
the near future, at which time the
exact date of the banquet will be
announced.

Five French runners from the
University of Paris are now in
training in Philadelphia in preparation for their participation in
the Penn Belay Carnival on April
99 and 30. These entries will run
in the sprint medley on the first
day of the meet, but will not take

W. E. Pope,
writing in the
Alumni Weekly, Princeton, gives
some interesting statistics on higher education in America. They
show that during the past thirty
years the enrollment of our colleges and universities has increased nearly 500 per cent. In
1890 there was an enrollment of
65,000; in 1900, 109,000; in 1910,
183,000; in 1920, 324,000.

To the Edtior of The Vetrs-Letter:
Sir—Mr. Robert K. Guggenheimer's letter in the issue of
April 19—advocating that preference in matriculation be given
those whose parents have attended
the University—has excited a distinct sentiment of "righteous indignation."
The doctrine is a very comfortable one for Mr. Guggenheimer
and those who are blessed, as he
is, with fortunate progenitors.
However, even the best of us are
rarely present when college-bred
sires are being distributed to prospective offspring. Say I, of two
men who seek entrance, admit him
who has singled Hopkins.out from
many, rather than him who comes
here merely because of family custom.
A gentleman more or less prominently connected with the University, whose opinion, I am sure,
carries weight with Mr. Guggenheimer, urged unequivocally at the
Commemoration Exercises that
the limitation of incoming students be based solely upon the
criterion of sheer personal superiority.
Autocracy in education, if necessary; but let it be the autocracy
of merit, not of birth.
F. W.
Miltimore. April 20. 1921.

TRACK SQUAD BY SIX

Hopkins Runners Capture Seven Firsts
and Four Seconds Out of Eight
Track Events—Weakness in
Field Events Causes
Defeat.

Running on the water-soaked
track at Swarthmore last Saturday with heavy showers falling at
frequent intervals, the Hopliins
track team lost to the Garnet aggregation by the close score of 59
to 53.
The Quakers owe their victory
almost entirely to their superiority
in the field events, as the Black
and Blue runners captured seven
first places and four seconds in
the eight track events. The Hopkins team was considerably weakened by the absence of Captain
who were
Mulliken and
the trip, but it nevunable to takeAaronson,
ertheless put up such a good fight
that the result of the meet was uncertain until the last event had
been run.
In spite of the poor condition
of the track, some of the times
made were remarkably good.
Clarke, who won both the 100 and
220-yard dashes, covered the latter
distance in 224A seconds. Somerville also carried off individual
honors by taking first place in
both the mile and two-mile runs.
"Joe" Thompson, who has been
laid up for some time with an injured leg and who ran on Saturday more as an experiment than
anything, showed that he will
soon be back in the game by finishing a close third in the 440 with
apparently little effort. The event
was won by Edwards, who displayed his unusual splendid form,
sprinting past Spacknian of
Swarthmore on the home stretch
and breaking the tape 54 seconds
after the starter's gun had been
fired. Considering the conditions
under which the race was run,
this was very good time.

LACROSSE TEAM DOWNS
PENN IN FIRST LEAGUE
GAME OF SEASON.
Muddy Field Mars Play and Makes
Good Stickwork Almost Impossible — Greee Material Is
Showing Up in Fine
Form—Score 9 to 2.

In the first league game of the
year Hopkins defeated Pennsylvania, 9 to 2, at •Homewood on
Saturday. Due to the bad weather, only a small crowd was on
hand, but those who braved the
rain were treated to a fine game
of lacrosse. Pennsylvania put out
a much stronger team than usual.
Their stickwork was good; they
were fast and aggressive, and had
lots of fight. The lead of seven
goals does not, however, by any
Means show the comparative
strength of the two teams. The
wet, muddy field put both teams •
on an equality, making the running hard, dodging almost impossible and the bouncing of the ball
erratic. The stickwork was below
standard at times also, due to the
wet ball slipping out of the stick.
Had the field been a dry one the
score would without doubt have
been greater. Throughout the
game Hopkins showed a strong attack, good teamwork and the ability to shoot hard and accurately
after the ball had been worked
The point that
dOWn the field.
was especially noticeable was how
well the midfield worked in with
the close attack, and with several
weeks more practice it looks as if
the coaches will have developed
out of green material an attack
that will equal Hopkins' best.
The defense also played a strong
game, although its part was not
as heavy Saturday as that of the
attack. Zoller broke up play after
play. While at goal Benedict
stopped any number Of hard shots.
:Navy beat Penn 10 to 0 on a dry
field; we beat them 9 to 2 on a
wet field. All we can say is
"Bring on Navy!"
Parsons shot the first goal of
the day with a pretty shot after
clever passing by Zoller and Huey.
Griffiss made the next two goals,
both of them being hard corner
shots from the side of the field.
He was the only man who seemed
to be able to keep his feet when
running hard, and his dodging
was one of the features of the
game. Prengle scored for Penn at
this time on a pass from Kiviat
over goal. Bauernschinidt, who
substituted for McDaniel, made
the last score of the half by picking up the ball off the ground and
making a pretty corner shot.
Penn came back strong in the
second half, and except for one
goal by Boyd held Hopkins score(Continued on page 4 col. 3)

BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 26, 1921
MUSICAL CLUBS SCORE HIT
IN CHURCH CONCERT.
Franklin Square Baptists Applaud Selections—All Performers in Fine
Form—University Ode Well
Received.

The Johns Hopkins combined
si cal clubs presented an unusually -snappy" and successful concert at the Franklin Square Baptist Church on Thursday evening,
April 21. The University Ode sung
by the Glee Club deserves silecial
mention, judging by the lasting
applause of an appreciative audience. As usual, the Glee Club and
the Mandolin Club were led by
"Doug" Coulter and "Mike" Bowers, respectively.
The concert began with a selection played by the orchestra. The
members of the Mandolin Club
distinguished themselves in rendering the "dreamily" waltz, "Hiawatha's Melody of Love." Next on
the program was "On the Road to
Mandalay." Eric Calkins sang the
solo part with great brilliancy. A
second solo took place later in the
evening when Waldo Hambleton
played "The Rosary" on his steel
guitar. According to the colored
sexton of the church, the -jazz" orchestra was "de hole sho" when it
jazzed up, -I Never. Knew." The
Barcarole played by the Mandolin
Club brought a successful evening
to a close. Although the hall was
small, it was filled to its capacity
by a large and appreciative audience.
MIKE BOWERS IS AT IT
AGAIN.
Starts a Student Band, Which Shows
Great Promise—Will Perform at
All Games.

Through the untiring efforts of
"Mike" Bowers, Hopkins has taken
another step in the right direction
with the successful organization
of a student band. After several
fruitless attempts, "Mike," assisted bv C. R. Tatun and backed by
Mr. -Kistler and Mr. Van Orman,
has brought together enough musicians to form a strong organization.
A great deal of interest is being
shown throughout the studentbody toward the movement. There
are at present some twenty-four
members, but it is expected that
many more will join the ranks before very long. Practice is held
two afternoons a week at the Barn,
and from the tone of the last rehearsal, it seemed as though this
band will compare_ favorably with
that of Lafayette, which is said to
be the best college band in the
country.
The band is to furnish music at
all the Saturday afternoon con-

ANNUAL TRIANGULAR DEBATE TAKES PLACE NEXT
SATURDAY.

SOUTHERN INTERCOLLEGIATE NEWSPAPER ASSOCIATION FORMED.

Washington and Lee Meets North Carolina at Homewood—Immigration
Is Subject—Dance Will Follow Debate — Hopkins
Teams Speak Away.

Nearly Forty Delegates From Seven
Southern States Present at Richmond Conference — Cotton
and Miller Rpresent the
News-Letter.

On this Saturday, April 30, the
annual triangular debate between
North Carolina, Washington and
Lee and Johns Hopkins will be
held. As has been the custom in
the past, all three meetings will be
held the same night, with the two
teams of each institution debating
away from home. Accordingly,
the negative team of North Carolina will try conclusions with the
affirmative team from 'Washington
and Lee in the C. E. Hall at Homewood, while the Hopkins affirmative debaters Dorsey Watkins and
Parker Williams are at Chapel
Hill, N. C., meeting the Washington and Lee men, and the negative
team, Adolphus Emmart and Albert Dimond, visit Lexington with
the Tar Heel speakers.
The subject of the debate is "Resolved, that the United States
should adopt a policy of further
material restriction of immigration."
Following the debate, "Mike"
Bowers and his cohorts will fuynish the necessary cacaphony for
an informal dance. Admission to
the hall is prohibited after 8.30;
hence, those who wish to dance
must also be present for the debate. Tickets may be obtained
from Bartus Trew, O. D. Collins
and R. M. Wood.

Charles F. Leet, editor-in-chief
of the Richmond Collegian, the
the weekly publication of the University of Richmond, was last Saturday elected president of the
Southern Intercollegiate Newspaper Association. This association
of the college newspapers of institutions below the Mason and
Dixon line formally began its first
year with the adoption of a constitution and by-laws at the first
annual convention, held at the
University of Richmond last Friday and Saturday.
Nearly twoscore delegates, representing the publications of 20
colleges in seven Southern States,
registered at convention headquarters Friday morning, most of them
ha -ing arrived in Richmond that
morning or the night before. The
conference was opened with an address • of welcome by Dr. F. W.
Boatwright, president of the university, after which Mr. Leek was
elected temporary chairman of the
meeting. After the usual preliminary business and an address iy
Mr. John Stewart Bryan, secretary American Newspaper Publishers' Association, the conference adjourned for luncheon, and
in the afternoon took a tour of inspection through the plant of the
Richmond Erening Dispatch. At
the banquet held that night the attention of the delegates was held
by the remarkable addresses of
Dr. John W. Camlitie, director of
the School of Journalism, Columbia UniverSity, and Dr. Douglas
Freeman, editor of the Richmond
Yeirs-Leader.
The conference was reopened
the next morning by a talk by
Frank M. Dobson, athletic director of the university, who took
as his subject "College Athletes
and the College Paper." Reports
of the several committees were
next presented, the committee on
organization, of which H. D. Cotton, who, with N. E. Miller, Jr.,
represented Johns Hopkins at hte
convention, was chairman, placing before the delegates a proposed constitution and by-laws
which, after a few changes, were
accepted.
The chief object of the association is to draw together, for the
purpose of closer co-operation, the
college newspapers of the South.
Practically all of these papers are

At a meeting of Omicron Delta
Kappa, held last Friday, several
new men were elected to membership. Their names will be made
public on May 12, when a public
initiation will be held at the Assembly.
tests at "Homewood," and will
also be on hand at other student
gatherings. Mr. Kistler made an
announcement to the effect that
all members of the band would
have the same rating as members
of the athletic teams in that they
would be presented with complimentary tickets to the games. This
announcement should do much to
increase both the spirit and the
number of the musicians.
The organizer should certainly
be congratulated for his great success. Just such an organization
has long been needed on the Hopkins Campus to stir up interest.
As Mr. Van Orman has said, "A
band does as much to stir up school
spirit as a football team."

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, APRIL 26, 1921

BLUE JAY
AND
FACULTY COMMITTEE ON , BLACK
COMES OUT THIS MONTH
MILITARY ACTIVITIES
WITH A BANG.
APPOINTED.
Emphasizes Growth of Importance of
R. 0. T. C. at Hopkins—Unit Getting in Trim for "Distinguished" Inspection.

"Wine, Woman and Song" Leaves Out
Likker and Jazz, But the Women
Are Right There—Will Issue
a Song Book Shortly.

President Goodnow has recently
appointed a Military Committee of
the faculty to co-ordinate the activities of the University and those
Ithe Department of Military
Science and Tactics. The coni'mittee has as chairman, Prof. J.
Herbert Gregory, as vice-chairman,
Dr. William B. Kouwenhoven, and
as secretary, Dr. Ronald T. Abercrombie. The members of the committee are at present making themselves familiar with the technical
details of the work of the military
department. The committee is designed to form a connecting link
between the military department
and the board of collegiate studies.
It has been constituted, moreover,
with the idea of being a University
check on the activities of the military department, and it is believed
that it will form, in the future, a
most useful and constructive body
in fitting the military activities in
with University traditions and
policy. The idea of such a committee was originated some months
ago bv Major Garey, and its establishment marks the recognition on
the part of the faculty of the important place the military department has won for itself among similar institutions throughout the
country.
The percentage of Johns Hopkins men attending R. 0. T. C.
slimmer camp this year is greater,
it is believed, than that of any
other institution in the country.
Major Garey, senior instructor at
the Plattsburg Camp, intends to
grade both individuals and institutions at the camp on their efficiency and ability. A special class
has been formed here for study
preparatory to the subsequent
work at camp, with the purpose of
putting . this institution number
one at Plattsburg.
The finishing touches for this
year's inspection for rating as a
"distinguished" unit are being put
upon the drill of the battalion.
The inspectors this year will be
from the Third Corps Area, instead of from the General Staff at
Washington, as formerly. Our
commandant appeals to the members of the R. 0. T. C. to put their
every effort into the military work
until the end of the year, in order
that we primarily may serve well
the interests of national defense,
and secondarily may come out
with an exceedingly high average
in comparison with other Units.
Major Garey also expressed himself as wishing the sympathy and
moral backing of the entire University in the accomplishment of
these objects.

The wine, women and song number of the Black and Blue Jay
"casts a thunderbolt into the generally dignified campus at Homewood," according to the Baltimore
8un. It compliments the staff on
producing a "snappy" number and
quotes a few articles which were
considered to produce the "pep."
Nor is this all. The general concensus of opinion seems to accept
this issue as the best of the year.
The Grad's number, however, in
which the Jay makes its final flutter of the term, promises to exceed
,its predecessor in "snappiness" if
it receives the support of the university.
The magazine is essentially a
representative of the student-body
and as such deserves unlimited
aid by way of contributions.
A song book is being planned by
the Jay and will probably make
its debut sometime next year. This
does not mark a divergence from
the ordinary line of university publications, for they are used by
nearly all the leading colleges.
This book will include all of the
old traditional songs of Hopkins,
as well as a great number of new
ones. The faculty and the 0. D. K.
are backing this undertaking
strongly, and it is conceded by all
that a song book represents a progressive step at Homewood.
NOTED

ORNITHOLOGIST
LECTURES.

"Migration of Birds" Subject of Lec••
ture.

The Scientific Club was addressed las Friday, April 22, by
Dr. H. C. Oberholser, of the Smithsonian Institution, Washington,
D. C. Quite a large audience was
present to hear the ornithologist
lecture on "The Migration of
Birds."
There are, he said, two theories
of the origin of migration.
First, that the birds migrated
from the tropics, due to overcrowding, and second, that they, originally occupying the galcial zone,
were driven away by the sheets of
ice.
All birds do not migrate. The
migrants, however, are followed
by means of leg-bands and much
interesting data has been compiled.
The birds travel mostly at night,
at rates varying from 20 to 150
miles an hour, and covering distances as great as 11,000 miles.
The normal migration, however, is
about 2000 miles.
The birds frequently return to
their first breeding grounds, travelling entirely by instinct.

29, the club will again visit Towson to present a concert for Eddie

in number, so men wishing to attend should purchase tickets from
any member of the club as soon as
possible in order to be accommodated.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LE FTER, APRIL 26, 1921
DRAMATIC CLUB WILL HAVE
AN ADVISORY COUNCIL
OF ALUMNI.
Will Help Maintain Standards of Club.
Aid in Selection of Production and
Cast—Banquet and Election
Planned.

After much deliberation and a
conference in the studio last Tuesday the Dramatic Club has decided
to create an Advisory Council to
assist in forming the policy of the
club and in keeping it up to the
standards it has held during the
three years of its existence. The
definite plans as to the powers of
this Advisory Council will be formulated after various suggestions
are brought up at a meeting today
in the Barn. In all probability it
will consist of from three to five
members, alumni of the University
and former members of the club,
who will be chosen annually. It
will have a voice in choosing the
annual major production and will
spend a great part of its time in
reviewing plays suitable for a Hopkins cast. The choice of a coach
will be wholly in its hands. It is
not intended that this council shall
in any way be mandatory or arbitrary, but that it shall submit
plans and give advice which will
assist in maintaining a high standard of production. Through it
the older members will keep in active touch with the activities of
the club.
Further plans are being made
for the production of several oneact playlets in the studio. It is
hoped that a 'Play-night" can be
arranged for the early part of May.
- An informal banquet, at which officers for next year will be chosen,
will be held at the Johns Hopkins Club.
JUNIOR CLASS DOES A LOT
AT ONE MEETING.
Banquet Committee Appointed — Banquet at Chateau Hotel—Editor and
Manager of Hullabaloo Elected.

A meeting of the Junior Class
was held last Thursday, at 2.20 in
the C. E. Hall.
President Hall announced that
the banquet committee had made
arrangements for the banquet to
be held in the roof-,garden of The
Chateau, the price to be about
$4.00 a plate. As in former years,
satisfactory entertainment will be
provided. The committee is composed of Naviasky (chairman),
Hensel, Johnston and Frank.
Following the election' to the
class of several new members, announcement was made by Huey
that class pictures were on hand
and copies might be purchased.
The rest of the meeting was devoted to the election of Editor and
Business Manager of the Hullabaloo for next year. Dorsey Watkins, secretary of last year, was
elected to fill the first office, while
Huey was selected for the post of
Business Manager.
Another meeting will be held in
the near future, at which time the
exact date of the banquet will be
announced.

Growth of Colleges.

Five French runners from the
University of Paris are now in
training in Philadelphia in preparation for their participation in
the Penn Belay Carnival on April
99 and 30. These entries will run
in the sprint medley on the first
day of the meet, but will not take
part in the two-mile event,

W. E. Pope,
writing in the
Alumni Weekly, Princeton, gives
some interesting statistics on higher education in America. They
show that during the past thirty
years the enrollment of our colleges and universities has increased nearly 500 per cent. In
1890 there was an enrollment of
65,000; in 1900, 109,000; in 1910,
183,000; in 1920, 324,000.

All letters intended for publication

To the Edtior of The Vetrs-Letter:
Sir—Mr. Robert K. Guggenheimer's letter in the issue of
April 19—advocating that preference in matriculation be given
those whose parents have attended
the University—has excited a distinct sentiment of "righteous indignation."
The doctrine is a very comfortable one for Mr. Guggenheimer
and those who are blessed, as he
is, with fortunate progenitors.
However, even the best of us are
rarely present when college-bred
sires are being distributed to prospective offspring. Say I, of two
men who seek entrance, admit him
who has singled Hopkins.out from
many, rather than him who comes
here merely because of family custom.
A gentleman more or less prominently connected with the University, whose opinion, I am sure,
carries weight with Mr. Guggenheimer, urged unequivocally at the
Commemoration Exercises that
the limitation of incoming students be based solely upon the
criterion of sheer personal superiority.
Autocracy in education, if necessary; but let it be the autocracy
of merit, not of birth.
F. W.
Miltimore. April 20. 1921.

GARNET TEAM
TRACK SQUAD BY SIX
POINTS IN DUAL
MEET.
Hopkins Runners Capture Seven Firsts
and Four Seconds Out of Eight
Track Events—Weakness in
Field Events Causes
Defeat.

Running on the water-soaked
track at Swarthmore last Saturday with heavy showers falling at
frequent intervals, the Hopliins
track team lost to the Garnet aggregation by the close score of 59
to 53.
The Quakers owe their victory
almost entirely to their superiority
in the field events, as the Black
and Blue runners captured seven
first places and four seconds in
the eight track events. The Hopkins team was considerably weakened by the absence of Captain
who were
Mulliken and
the trip, but it nevunable to takeAaronson,
ertheless put up such a good fight
that the result of the meet was uncertain until the last event had
been run.
In spite of the poor condition
of the track, some of the times
made were remarkably good.
Clarke, who won both the 100 and
220-yard dashes, covered the latter
distance in 224A seconds. Somerville also carried off individual
honors by taking first place in
both the mile and two-mile runs.
"Joe" Thompson, who has been
laid up for some time with an injured leg and who ran on Saturday more as an experiment than
anything, showed that he will
soon be back in the game by finishing a close third in the 440 with
apparently little effort. The event
was won by Edwards, who displayed his unusual splendid form,
sprinting past Spacknian of
Swarthmore on the home stretch
and breaking the tape 54 seconds
after the starter's gun had been
fired. Considering the conditions
under which the race was run,
this was very good time.

GRADUATE SCHOOL OF

BUSINESS ADMINISTRATION
A two-year course in business leading
to the degree of Master of Business Administration.
Open to college graduates.
Courses offered in the following fields:
Accounting, Business Law, Banking and
Finance, Marketing,Advertising, Retail
Store Problems, Sales Management, Industrial Management, Labor Problems,
Business Statistics. Foreign Trade,
Transportation, Lumbering. Office Organization.
Five graduates of Johns Hopkins
University have attended the School,
two during the present year.
The registration for 1921-22 is limited
to three hundred in the first year
courses. Applications after May 1st
should be accompanied by a certified
transcript of the college record.
For information write to
